title-group.article-title: Composite proton conducting membrane by radiation-induced grafting of 1-vinylimidazole onto poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene) and phosphoric acid doping

contrib-group.aff: Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Institute of Hydrogen Economy, Energy Research Alliance, Jalan Semarak, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: Mohamed Mahmoud Nasef, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Institute of Hydrogen Economy, Energy Research Alliance, Jalan Semarak, Kuala Lumpur, 54100, Malaysia. Email: mahmoudeithar@cheme.utm.my

abstract.p: Composite membrane containing phosphoric acid (PA) for possible use in a fuel cell was prepared by radiation-induced grafting of 1-vinylimidazole (1-VIm) onto poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene) (ETFE) films followed by protonation with PA doping. The preparation procedure involved three steps: (i) irradiation of ETFE films by an electron beam, (ii) grafting of 1-VIm onto the irradiated films under selected conditions and (iii) doping the grafted film with PA. The membrane composition, thermal properties and thermal stability were evaluated using Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis and differential scanning calorimetry, respectively. The obtained membrane was found to have a degree of grafting of 54% and 6.6 mmol PA per poly-VIm repeating unit with ionic conductivity of 140 mS cm−1 at 120°C and ∼20% relative humidity. The overall results suggest that the membrane has a promising combination of physicochemical properties appealing for possible application in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell above 100°C.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fuel cells are power systems with high potentials for environmentally friendly conversion of the chemical energy of a fuel into an electrical energy in the presence of an oxidant via electrocatalyst. Polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM), which is normally sandwiched between two platinum (Pt)-loaded carbon fabric electrodes, is the heart of the fuel cell system. PEM acts as a barrier preventing the bulk mixing of H2 (fuel) and O2/air (oxidant) and selectively transporting the H+ generated at the anode to the cathode.

PEM fuel cells (PEMFCs) with commercial perfluorosulfonic membranes, such as Nafion® and its analogous materials, operate at 80°C to suit the water-dependence mechanism of proton conductivity and tolerate the variation in their viscoelastic properties. 1 Thus, water humidification system is installed to prevent the membrane drying and over wetting. However, this adversely adds up to PEMFC overall cost and complexity. Hence, a demand for operating PEMFC at a temperature above 100°C is being sought. 2 This is to enhance the efficiency through better electrode kinetics, reduce or eliminate humidification system, enhance the tolerance to fuel impurities and allow utilization of excess heat for cogeneration. 3

Phosphoric acid (PA)/polybenzimadazole (PBI) membranes were proposed as alternatives for PEMFC. The incorporation of PA into the structure through doping with PBI yields an acid–base complex membrane capable of conducting protons at elevated temperature. This prompted various investigations leading to PA/PBI membranes with reasonable performance in PEMFC at temperatures up to 190°C without any additional humidification. 4

The synthesis of PA/PBI membranes often involves polymerization followed by either: (1) doping with PA and direct casting of the doped PBI solution or (2) casting PBI into film followed by PA doping. However, both these routes lead to the formation of membranes with different physicochemical properties despite the similarity in acid doping level. Moreover, casting of PBI or PA/PBI into a thin defect- (pinhole-) free, even and uniform membrane is highly a challenging task. In addition, the conductivity of PA/PBI membranes above 100°C is lower than their corresponding values of perfluorosulfonic membranes operated at 80°C.

Recently, similar composite membranes prepared by PA doping of precursor-grafted films obtained by radiation-induced grafting (RIG) of heterocyclic monomers such as 4-vinylpyridine onto poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene) (ETFE) was found to be attractive alternative materials for high temperature PEMFC. 5 The use of RIG simplifies the preparation procedure, allows close control over the composition and overall properties of the membranes in addition to providing a solution for the membrane shaping by starting the reaction with a ready-made film compared with the synthesis of PBI precursors by conventional polymerization. 6 Also, the availability of various heterocyclic monomers and polymer film combinations provides a number of basic membrane precursors varying in their strengths, compositions and properties. However, reports on radiation-grafted and PA-doped composite membranes for high temperature PEMFC are very scarce despite the large number of similar studies dealing with radiation-grafted sulfonic acid membranes. Thus, further exploration for the potential of RIG method in producing alternative membrane PA-doped membranes is sought.

The objective of this article is to present an alternative less-water-dependent acid/base proton conducting membrane with high ionic conductivity for possible use in high temperature PEMFC. The membrane is obtained by RIG of 1-vinylimidazole (1-VIm) onto ETFE film followed by PA doping. The 1-VIm monomer was selected to provide a basic center (–N=) resembling that of PBI to conduct protons at temperatures above 100°C when protonated by PA doping. On the other hand, the use of ETFE film as a base polymer is due to its outstanding properties including chemical inertness, thermal stability and mechanical integrity, in addition to, high radiation resistance. 7

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: ETFE film of 125 µm thickness and 1.69 g cm− 3 density was purchased from Goodfellow Cambridge Ltd (England). 1-VIm (Fluka, Switzerland) with purity >99% was used without further purification. Hydrochloric acid (HCl; 37%) and PA (85%) were obtained from J.T. Bakers (Philipsburg, NJ, USA). A deionized water used in all the experiments was produced using NANOpure® DIamond™ water purifier.

sec.title: Irradiation of ETFE film
sec.p: The ETFE film was cut into a desired size and carefully washed with methanol followed by drying in a vacuum oven. The clean film was kept into a thin polyethylene bag, which was evacuated and sealed. The film was irradiated using a universal electron beam accelerator (NHV-Nissin High Voltage, EPS 3000, Cockroft Walton type, Japan) operated at an acceleration voltage of 2 MeV and 10 kGy per pass. The film was irradiated to a total dose of 100 kGy. After irradiation, the film was kept in a low temperature freezer at −65°C prior to use.

sec.title: Grafting of 1-VIm onto irradiated ETFE film
sec.p:
Grafting reaction was performed by introducing a mixture of 1-VIm diluted with water (60:40 v/v) into the irradiated ETFE film in a special ampoule, which was then flushed for 30 min with a purified N2 to remove air and then sealed tightly. The ampoule was kept in a water bath at a temperature of 60°C for 16 h. Subsequently, the grafted film (membrane precursor) was removed, washed with 0.1 M HCl solution and rinsed therein under sonication for 16 h to remove the residues of the monomer and homopolymer from the film surfaces. The film was extracted and washed with a hot-water prior to vacuum drying. Details of grafting reaction under various parameters and its optimization were reported elsewhere. 8 The degree of grafting (DG (%)) was calculated from the increase in weight in the film after grafting as follows 1

where w o and w g are the weights of the original and grafted ETFE films, respectively.

sec.title: Acid doping of grafted ETFE film
sec.p: The grafted film was doped with PA under N2 atmosphere using a 50% acid solution at 30°C for 5 days in a glass reactor. The membranes were washed with deionized water few times and dried overnight at 80°C in a vacuum oven.

The acid doping level per repeated unit of polymer was calculated as follows 2

where X d is the doping level (millimoles of PA per repeat unit of poly-VIm (PVIm)), w d is the mass fraction of the dopant, M p is the molar mass of the repeating unit (grams per moles (g mol−1)), w i is the percentage of weight increase of the grafted films and M d is the molar mass of the dopant (g mol−1).

sec.title: Properties of grafted films and acid-doped membranes
sec.p: Fourier-transformed infrared (FTIR) measurements of samples were recorded on a Nicolet 5700 spectrophotometer in a transmittance mode at a frequency range of 4000–500 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The spectra of the samples were detected and analyzed using commercial software (Essential FTIR™).

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the samples was performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851 analyzer. All the heating runs were made in a temperature range of 50–700°C at a constant heating rate of 20°C min−1 and under N2 atmosphere.

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were recorded on a Mettler Toledo DSC 822 analyzer under N2 atmosphere in a temperature range of 50–300°C at a constant heating rate of 20°C min−1. The degree of crystallinity of the grafted film and PA-doped membrane was calculated by taking the heat of melting of a 100% crystalline polymer (113.4 J g−1) into account and correcting the recorded heat of melting by dividing over the weight fraction of ETFE in the grafted film and membrane as described elsewhere. 9

The thickness of the membrane was measured using a digital thickness gauge (Mitutoyo, Japan). The level swelling was measured in deionized water and calculated from the weight difference between the membrane in wet and dry conditions.

The ionic conductivity of the membrane was measured at a temperature range of 30–120°C using a 4-probe conductivity cell (Bekktech, Loveland, CO, USA) connected to a DC source meter (Keithley 2400, Keithly Instruments Inc., Cleveland, OH, USA) and controlled by Lab view software. The membrane was cut into the strips of 3 × 350 mm2 size, which was clamped between the Pt electrodes and placed in the externally insulated conductivity cell equipped with thermocouples and temperature controller. The relative humidity (RH (%)) inside the conductivity cell was maintained in the range of 20–100% by means of preconditioned humidified N2. The gas conditioning was performed using a humidification system equipped with humidifier, temperature controller, thermocouple and gas flow meter. The RH was detected by a humidity sensor attached to the conductivity cell and interfaced with the computer. The ionic conductivity (σ, S cm−1) was calculated according to the following equation 3
σ =
1 R
L A

where L is the thickness of the membrane sample (cm), A is the surface area of the sample (cm2) and R is the electrical resistance (ohms). The ionic conductivity of Nafion 117 was measured in a fully hydrated condition from moisture at 30°C in a similar manner and used as a reference.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: A membrane with a DG of 54% was prepared by RIG of 1-VIm onto ETFE film at 60% 1-VIm concentration diluted with water, 100 kGy absorbed dose of radiation, 60°C reaction temperature and 16 h grafting time followed by a treatment with a 50% PA solution at 30°C for 5 days. To provide evidences for grafting and PA doping, FTIR analysis was performed on the membrane in comparison with the original and grafted ETFE films as shown in the FTIR spectra presented in Figure 1. The spectrum of ETFE film displayed a number of strong bands in the range of 1000–1400 cm−1 resembling C–F of CF2 groups, in addition to, a small band at 2915 cm−1 representing stretching vibrations of CH2 groups. The grafted films prevailed additional characteristic bands representing CN groups in the range of 1525–1575 cm−1. The bands at 2750–3150 cm−1 and 3200–3650 cm−1 were assigned for N–H and C–H of the grafted imidazole rings, respectively, which are mostly involved in a network of H-bonding between the imidazole rings and the moisture as expected from their amphoteric behavior. 5 The spectrum of PA-doped membrane showed broad bands in the range of 2100–3600 cm− 1. This trend agrees completely with the behaviour of other PA membranes reported in the literature and can be attributed to the formation of H-bonding and hydrogen phosphate groups. 5,10 Hence, it is reasonable to suggest the plausible mechanism shown in Figure 2 for PA-doped membrane prepared in the present study.

caption.p: FTIR spectra of (a) original ETFE film, (b) grafted ETFE film and (c) PA-doped membrane. FTIR: Fourier-transformed infrared; ETFE: poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene); PA: phosphoric acid.

Plausible mechanism of preparation of PA-doped membrane by radiation-induced grafting with 1-VIm onto ETFE film followed by phosphorylation. ETFE: poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene); PA: phosphoric acid; 1-VIm: 1-vinylimidazole.

sec.p: The thermal stability of the membrane was investigated with TGA in comparison with the grafted and original ETFE films and the obtained thermograms are presented in Figure 3.

caption.p: TGA thermograms of (a) original ETFE film, (b) grafted ETFE film and (c) PA-doped membrane. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; ETFE: poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene); PA: phosphoric acid.

sec.p: The original ETFE film has a single-step degradation pattern at 435°C, whereas the grafted ETFE film showed a three-step degradation pattern at 128, 322 and 435°C, respectively. This is due to the dehydration of moisture traces involved in H-bonding with the basic imidazole rings, decomposition of PVIm grafts and decomposition of ETFE molecular chains. Interestingly, the grafted PVIm was found to be incompatible with ETFE backbone leading to the formation of phase separated domains in the grafted films as indicated by the transitions at 322 and 435°C, respectively. Since grafting is well-known to occur in amorphous regions close to the crystal lamellae, the incompatibility trend can be attributed to the difference in the nature of the grafted polyimidazoles, which is fully amorphous from the crystalline fraction of (semicrystalline) ETFE matrix. The thermogram of the acid-doped membrane displayed a three-step degradation pattern started at 120°C by dehydration followed by continuous decomposition caused by depolymerization of the grafted polyimidazole and removal of phosphoric at 320°C and subsequent decomposition of ETFE molecular chains at 420°C. The beginning of degradation of the membrane was found to be 8°C lower than (120°C) that of the grafted film (128°C), and this is due to the higher moisture content in the PA-doped membrane. The absence of any distinction between the decomposition transitions of P(VIm) and that of PA is due to their close thermal degradation temperatures. These results are in a good agreement with similar PA-doped membranes obtained by grafting various basic vinyl monomer onto fluorinated polymer films. 5,8,11 From the TGA results, it can be suggested that the membrane is suitable for testing in a high temperature PEMFC up to 200°C.

DSC thermograms of the original ETFE, grafted films and PA-doped membrane are shown in Figure 4. The melting point (T m) of the original ETFE film was captured at 263°C, and shifted to 261°C with a coincided reduction in the melting peak area after grafting of 1-VIm. The T m was lowered to 260°C with a rise in the reduction of melting peak area after doping the grafted film with PA. Such a slight shift in T m suggests a minute partial disruption developed during membrane preparation procedure (grafting and doping). Moreover, the reduction in the melting peak area are substantially due to the dilution of the crystalline region of ETFE with the amorphous P(VIm) grafts. This observation is going pretty well with the calculated degrees of crystallinity (X c), which showed a reduction from 34.2 to 27.5 in the original ETFE film and 25.2 in the grafted ETFE films and PA-doped membrane, respectively. Nevertheless, the membrane maintains a reasonable level of X c despite the dilution effect and minor disruption in its crystalline structure.

caption.p: DSC thermograms of (a) original ETFE film, (b) grafted ETFE films and (c) PA-doped membrane. DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; ETFE: poly(ethylene-co-tetrafluoroethylene); PA: phosphoric acid.

sec.p: Figures 5 and 6 show the results of ionic conductivity measurements in correlation with the temperature and RH% for PA-doped membrane. As can be seen, the conductivity was found to increase gradually with the increase in the temperature and the decrease in RH%. The conductivity recorded a maximum value of 140 mS cm−1 at a combination of 120°C and ∼20% RH. This suggests that PA-doped membrane obtained in this study is less-water dependent. In comparison, Nafion 117 membranes showed an ionic conductivity of 156 mS cm−1 when tested in a fully hydrated condition (100% RH at 30°C), which is almost double that of the corresponding value for PA membrane at room temperature. Such discrepancy may be understood taking into consideration that Nafion 117 membrane has a different structure involving covalently bonded sulfonic acid groups making its conductivity water-dependent.

caption.p: Variation in ionic conductivity of the membrane with temperature.
Variation in ionic conductivity of the membrane with relative humidity.

sec.p: The dependence of proton conductivity of PA-doped membrane on the temperature at the corresponding RH% was found to follow Arrhenius law as depicted from Figure 7, which depicts the log ionic conductivity versus 1000/T. This suggests the existence of a hopping-like conduction mechanism in the membranes. The activation energies between 30 and 120°C calculated from the Arrhenius plot were found to be 2.7 kJ mol−1. The results shown in Figures 5–7 can be explained taking into consideration that the incorporation of PA leads to the formation of protonated sites (NH+) in the membrane, which release H+ that starts hopping from the NH+ sites to PA anions along the anionic chains causing a continuous proton transfer. A proton hopping along the H2PO4 − anionic chain is also likely to contribute to the proton transfer, and this is supported by the presence of high acid doping level in this membrane. The presence of water in a form of bound water might also cause a proton hopping via water molecules contributing to proton conductivity but to a lower extent. The hopping increases with the increase in temperature leading to a significant increase in the conductivity. Such trend suggests that this membrane is highly conductive despite being less-water dependent. The results of this work are similar with the studies which suggested that the PA membranes have effective proton conductivity even in an anhydrous form. 4,12 Also, a similar temperature-dependent conductivity trend was reported for PA-doped PBI at 120°C 10,13 but with a lower conductivity value (9.6 mS cm−1) 4 when compared with the present membrane. The superior conductivity value of this membrane may be attributed to the presence of excess doped acids having lower affinity toward imidazole side chains, which have one imino nitrogen group allowing a high level of proton mobility unlike PA-doped PBI in which PA is likely to have high affinity to both imino nitrogen groups of imidazole attached to the bulk molecular chains in PBI matrix leading to less proton mobility.

caption.p: Arrhenius plot of log ionic conductivity versus reciprocal of temperature.

sec.p: Table 1 presents a summary of the physicochemical properties of radiation-grafted and PA-doped membrane when compared with PA-doped PBI and Nafion 117 membranes. As can be seen, the obtained membrane has an excellent combination of ionic conductivity, thermal stability, acid-doping level and physical strength, in addition to, reasonable swelling when compared with PA-doped PBI. Moreover, the ionic conductivity of radiation-grafted acid-doped membrane is superior when compared with that of PA dope PBI membrane as reported in the study by He et al., 4 despite its slightly higher doping level and thickness. It is also higher than that of Nafion 117 at 120°C (100% RH) by 65%. 14 This suggests that the membrane obtained in this study is a promising candidate for a high temperature PEMFC, provided it has a sufficient chemical stability.

caption.p: Summary of the physicochemical properties of radiation-grafted and PA-doped membranes compared with PA-doped PBI.

fn.p: PA: phosphoric acid; PBI: polybenzimadazole; RH: relative humidity; PVIm: polyvinylimidazole.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PA-doped proton conducting membranes having an attractive combination of properties were successfully prepared by RIG of 1-VIm onto ETFE films followed by PA doping. The membrane was found to have a thermal stability up to 200°C. It was also found to retain a reasonable level of crystallinity sufficient to maintain the physical strength necessary for the use as a polymer electrolyte in high temperature PEMFC. The ionic conductivity of the membrane increased with the increase in the temperature coupled with a parallel decrease in RH%. The membrane achieved the highest level of conductivity of 140 mS cm−1 at 120°C and RH as low as 20%. This suggests that the obtained membrane is less-water dependent, and it is a promising candidate for testing in PEMFC above 100°C provided it has sufficient chemical stability.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received fund from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia RU fund awarded by Malaysian Ministry of Higher Education.
